answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hello,
Unfortunately my search did not provide any contracts or agreements however I found a few documents that provide names of small and medium cities that have consolidated their water authorities. You may wish to contact the jurisdictions directly for further information. 
-   A document on the Knowledge Network called “Shared Services and Saving Tax Dollars” provides a list of jurisdictions in the appendix that have successfully consolidated services, including water systems. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301700/Sharing_Services_and_Saving_Tax_Dollars
-   In Pennsylvania, the Hampton Township Municipal Authority and Shaler Township Water Department have merged to create the Hampton-Shaler Water Authority. 
http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/11125/1144392-54.stm 
-   In New York, the City of Lockport and the City of North Tonawanda are creating the Tri-City Regional Water and Wastewater Optimization/ Consolidation Project. 
http://www.dos.state.ny.us/lg/lge-water_projects.html
-   In Kentucky, Kenton County Water District No. 1 was merged with Campbell County Water District in 1997 to create the Northern Kentucky Water District. 
http://nkapc.org/plan_pdf/01_kc_plan/Chapter07.pdf 
I hope this is useful,
Pooja Varma 
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org
